description:
Let's get straight to the point. Based on our numbers, the RTX 4070 Ti is basically a cheaper RTX 4080, knocking on the door of 4080 Super performance - and its $749 MSRP is cheaper than the outgoing 4070 Ti Super. We really like the card, DLSS 4 is a nice bonus - but real world pricing is crucial. Will you actually be able to buy one at its sticker price? Does the world actually need 'OC' models that add hundreds of dollars to the cost?

Look at all of our benchmarks in the Eurogamer review: https://www.eurogamer.net/digitalfoundry-2025-nvidia-geforce-rtx-5070-ti-review

Note: At 24:23, RTX 4090 is listed as a $1999 card - MSRP was actually $1599 and the $/Frame calculation comes from that actual MSRP

comments.text:
Missed my chance to grab a 4070 Ti Super last year. Went with a 4070 Super instead which is fine in all my games except when it comes to VR. I had contemplated getting the 5070 Ti pretty early on, but there was no way in hell I'd pay those looney-tunes prices they were asking for around launch. 
That said: I just ordered a 5070 Ti ...because in my neck of the woods prices have actually come down to below MSRP on some models. Which still doesn't say that much as I believe all these cards are overpriced even if you can get them at MSRP. 
In any case: I'm pretty sure I paid more or less exactly what I would've paid for a cheap as chips, 2-fan Inno3D 4070 Ti Super last year, so I decided it wasn't going to get any cheaper than that in the foreseeable future. Heck, there was even a limited sale on of the MSI Shadow for under EUR 800 (MSRP is 879 here), but since I'm not a fan of MSI's cheaper models or of plastic backplates on an 800 EUR GPU, I paid 40 EUR more and went with a Palit instead.

comments.text:
I'm curious about how frame generation scaling works in this scenario. Let's suppose the previous 40-series cards with single FG can generate one interpolated frame, taking X ms to generate. Now, let's assume the new 50-series cards with MFG are 3x faster at this, generating 3 interpolated frames in the same X ms. The cost of rendering a traditional frame remains Y ms for both.

Now, considering that for each user input, the movement on-screen between two standard frames should be 15 pixels:

For a 40-series card, after 2(Y + X) ms from the first standard frame, the second standard frame is shown (Y ms to render the second standard frame, which is held, X ms to generate the interpolated frame, which is shown immediately, and then another Y + X ms before the next standard frame to maintain frame time consistency).

For a 50-series card, with 4x FG, the time between two standard frames should be 4(Y + X) ms (Y ms to render the second standard frame, then after X ms, the three interpolated frames are generated and shown at Y + X ms intervals to maintain frame time consistency).


If this is the case, then 4x FG should add 2X the latency compared to just turning on FG (i.e., 2x FG). This should also mean that the latency increase between enabling 2x, 3x, and 4x FG should be consistent and predictable.

However, in real-world testing, increasing FG from 2x to 3x or 4x does not triple or quadruple the latency as expected. So, what exactly is happening here? Is Nvidia using some sort of adaptive pacing, frame reordering, or another optimization to reduce the expected input lag at higher FG multipliers?

comments.text:
Latency should work as follows.
Base latency = frame time + system latency

The base latency can fall no lower than the frame time.

Mfg does this (probably)
Latency = n * p + 2 * (base frame time) + system latency 
n = number of fake frames
p = time needed to generate one fake frame

This implies that each fake frame takes the same time. So this is probably an upper bound.

We could calculate these numbers.

comments.text:
Honestly publishing price per frame charts in 2025 is mildly interesting but largely useless now.

Since we have multiple generations where performance added has largely been matched or exceeded by price increases then, the previous gen cards are withdrawn from sale.  This means 2 things:

1. Both NVidia and AMD are telling the community that the minimimum reasonable mid range price for a graphics card is now = to what we called high end back in the 30 series days.

2. Neither company has any real care factor in this market, they are just doing the bare minimum to say they still sevice it.

What they fail to understand is that aside from those who must just have whatever the latest is regardless of price, the rest of us set a budget and will not exceed that budget. If nothing that is a worthwhile upgrade fits in that budget, we don't buy anything.

I bought a 3070 for about $550 US  back when it was first released. The 3070 was as fast as the previous gen 2080Ti, the flagship of the previous gen.

Even allowing for inflation since 2020, if I were going to buy a replacement for it now, my budget would go no higher than $600.

My other hard requirement is that it must have at least 16GB VRam.

With these 2 constraints, there are no new generation cards that I will buy.

I don't care about the fact that a 5070 ti is a huge fps increase. It is too expensive at MSRP, let alone $900, which is more what you would have to pay to actually get one. 

So, just buy the 5070 when it releases? Well no, because there is no way on this planet I am going to suffer poor textures and/or massive performance drops every time the frame buffer on a 12 GB card gets filled, when I am spending $550 (MSRP.. HAH!) in 2025. We don't spend this much to keep a card for a year, we pay this much expecting it to be decent for the next 5 years.

But AMD will come and save rhe day!.

No. They won't.  They delayed the rease of the 9070 and 9070 xt because they wanted to see if NVidia were lying about their MSRPs for 50 series. 

NVidia were lying, at least in any practical sense.

Therefore, AMD now know that in reality all they need to do is their usual under cut by $50 and have decent supply and they will sell, only they wont be undercutting the 5070 by $50 with these cards they will do it vs the 5070Ti and 5080 with the 9070 and 9070 XT respectively. 

So AMD will sell those cards at best at $650 & $750. Which will be mainly an upsell because the XT will look good vs the 5080.

Which still means that if you have a budget of $600 and a 16gb frame buffer requirement, you are screwed essentially until at least the next gen, or if literally neither company can shift inventory. 

While I would like to think the latter will happen there are enough stupid people out there that they probably will not need to.

And this is how you kill PC gaming.

comments.text:
@PositronCannon  I disagree with your perspective here. Historically we get new hardware and it either bolsters performance meaningfully or it ought to provide a meaningful savings with value for the end consumer. Nvidia is engaging in monopolistic behavior and providing poor value products for the money even factoring in inflation — they basically have shifted the entire product stack down, raised prices a lot over time, and they’ve been skimping on VRAM since at least the 3000 series. They can do all this because AMD has broadly failed to compete. Right now Intel’s new GPUs are basically the only ones providing genuine meaningful value to the end user.

Wby do so many folks defend this mega corp who are just trying to push pricing up hard and minimize value for their end user as much as they can get away with? Massive backlash is a very good thing for bad products as we saw with the whole 4080 12 gig debacle — it’s necessary and DF pulling their punches does not help the customer, it helps Nvidia.
comments.author: @BlindBison

comments.text: @ Massive backlash is done by not buying the product because you decide it's a bad value, not by angry thumbnails on YouTube videos. I'm not defending Nvidia at all, I'm defending DF for actually providing the kind of level-headed reviews I want to see in the modern Internet landscape which is the opposite of that. I can decide for myself based on the data whether the product is good value or not, I don't need it shouted at me.
comments.author: @PositronCannon

comments.text:
@PositronCannon   Most consumers are not mega fans who follow all the testing and price to perf data at a meticulous level like we do. Having folks like Gamers Nexus, DF, or HUB (etc) tell you what’s a good or bad product is really needed for most people. It’s also a hobby a lot of us care about deeply so when you’re looking forward to something and a company delivers a poor product — I believe Nvidia could have done better than this on price or VRAM for example — that’s going to frustrate people and they express it to others. It’s pretty normal and necessary to get the message out. The very best thing you can do for users (not Nvidia) is clearly spread a message that certain products are not good so that they don’t sell. 

DF basically said these cards adequate with a few points of mild criticism — they’re pulling their punches.

comments.text:
The SoC in the latest-and-greatest Android phones is about 125 square millimeters and goes into the $1300 S25 Ultra.
The A18 Pro in Apple's latest 16 Pro devices is 110 square millimeters.
The 5090's GPU is 744 square millimeters.
The 5070's GPU is 378 square millimeters.
Let's simplify to 100 mm for the A18 Pro and 800 for the 5090.
That means it would be 10x10 and 40x40.
For every one 5090, you'd get 16 A18 Pro chips using the same amount of silicon.

Also,
Every square millimeter you go up increases the likelihood of a defective chip.
If you encounter a defect in one A18 Pro, you can either bin that down to use in, say an iPad Air (still a ~$600 device) or throw it away and have 15 chips remaining, depending on the severity of the defect.
If you encounter a defect in in one 5090 (GB202), you might have to bin the cost equivalent of 16 A18 Pro chips or at best sell it for a huge discount on another product.
The ~20x20 for the 5070Ti (GB203)would mean you'd be throwing away four A18 Pro chips, etc.

The 5070Ti and 5080 both use the GB203, meaning the 5070Ti is, in essence, a defective 5080 that was cut down for exactly this reason.

The PS5 is 260 (slim) or 308 (OG) square mm.

comments.text:
It's the same process node as the previous generation. 40 series was a new node (4 nm), 30 series was a new node (8 nm), 20 series was a new node (12 nm), 10 series was a new node (16 nm and 14 nm).
The second most recent gen to re-use a process node was the Geforce 900 series, that used the same node as the 700 series.

Die shrinks are a great way to get "free" performance; without one, getting notably more performance without more power isn't easy.

comments.text:
@stangamer1151  That's because the 3000 series card was based on an 8nm process node, while the 4000 cards are TSMC 4nm.
Since then, no new process has become available for reasonable prices. TSMC 4nm is so in demand that its prices have increased by 15% since 2021, instead of decline like they normally do.
So the 5000 series is still based on the same 4nm process. Nvidia aren't delivering a 'full' generational improvement because the technology doesn't enable one for the next couple years.

Our choices are: Either we're limited to RTX 4000 for the next 2-5 years... or we accept a small upgrade with Blackwell. A big upgrade is simply not an option.
